TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, smectitic Eutric Glossocryalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Muggins sandy loam - forest.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
Oi--3 to 1 inches; undecomposed organic material principally needles, bark, twigs, and leaves.
Oe--1 to 0 inch; partially decomposed organic material like that of the horizon above; medium acid.
E--0 to 12 inches; pinkish gray (7.5YR 7/2) sandy loam, light brown (7.5YR 6/4) moist; weak medium platy structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; 10 percent pebbles and cobbles; slightly acid (pH 6.2); gradual wavy boundary.  (4 to 20 inches thick)
E/B--12 to 18 inches; pinkish gray (7.5YR 7/2) sandy clay loam, light brown (7.5YR 6/4) and reddish brown (5YR 5/4) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; peds are very hard, firm; few faint clay films on the more clayey portions of peds and discontinuous clay film coatings in root channels and pores; 10 percent cobbles; slightly acid (pH 6.4); gradual smooth boundary. (4 to 12 inches thick)
Bt--18 to 45 inches; light reddish brown (5YR 6/4) sandy clay, reddish brown (5YR 5/4) moist; moderate coarse and medium angular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, sticky and plastic; peds are extremely hard, very firm, many distinct clay films on faces of peds and in root channels and pores; clay film rims around the entrance to some pores; 10 percent cobbles; slightly acid (pH 6.2); gradual smooth boundary.  (6 to 44 inches thick)
BC--45 to 50 inches; light reddish brown (5YR 6/4) light sandy clay, reddish brown (5YR 5/4) moist; weak coarse angular blocky structure; hard, friable, sticky and plastic; peds are extremely hard, very firm; few faint clay films on faces of peds and in root channels and pores; 10 percent cobbles; moderately acid (pH 5.8); gradual smooth boundary.  (3 to 8 inches thick)
C--50 to 60 inches; light reddish brown (5YR 6/4) sandy clay loam, reddish brown (5YR 5/4) moist; massive; very hard, very firm, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; 10 percent cobbles; moderately acid (pH 5.8).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Summit County, Colorado; approximately 750 feet east of W1/4 corner Sec. 13, T. 5 S., R. 78 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Mean annual soil temperature is 36 to 42 degrees F. and mean summer soil temperature is about 49 to 52 degrees F.   Thin dark colored A horizons occur in some pedons.  Base saturation ranges from 60 to 100 percent.  Depth to the base of the argillic horizon ranges from 17 to 60 inches.  Rock fragments range from 0 to 35 percent in a major part of the solum and any C horizon and are mainly 1/2 to 10 inches in diameter.
Moisture regime: udic
The E horizon has hue of 10YR through 2.5YR, value of 5 through 8 dry, 4 through 7 moist, and chroma of 1 through 4.  It is neutral through strongly acid.
The Bt horizon has hue of 5YR or 2.5YR, value of 5 through 7, 4 through 6 moist, and chroma of 1 through 6.  Textures are clay loam, clay, or sandy clay but clay ranges from 35 to 55 percent, silt from 5 to 45 percent, and sand from 15 to 60 percent with more than 15 percent fine or coarse sand.  Reaction is neutral through moderately acid.
The C horizon has hue of 5YR through 10R.  It is typically loam, clay loam, or sandy clay loam but clay ranges from 18 to 35 percent, silt from 5 to 50 percent, and sand from 20 to 75 percent.  The horizon ranges from neutral to strongly acid.

COMPETING SERIES.content:
COMPETING SERIES: This is the Gateway series.
Gateway soils: moderately deep to a paralithic contact.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Muggins soils are on till plains, moraines, ridgetops, plateaus, or mountain side slopes.  Slopes range from about 2 to 65 percent.  These soils formed in thick reddish brown noncalcareous glacial till, colluvium, alluvial fans, residuum, or valley fillings deposits derived principally from sedimentary rock and interbedded sandstone and shale with basalt overburden.  Mean annual precipitation is about 26 to 37 inches with peak periods of precipitation in the spring and summer.  Mean annual temperature is 30 to 40 degrees F. and mean summer temperature is 51 to 55 degrees F.  Elevation ranges from 7,500 to 10,300 feet with the frost-free period varying widely from 20 to 75 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Chieftain, Swigton, and Weminuche soils.  Chieftain soils have a mollic epipedon, are calcareous at or near the surface, and have hue of 7.5YR or yellower.  Swifton and Weminuche soils have less than 35 percent clay in the argillic horizon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium to rapid runoff; slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used as grazing land, for timber production, and for recreation.  Native vegetation is aspen, spruce, fir, and lodgepole pine.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  North-central Colorado.  The series is of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic features include:  an argillic horizon - the zone from 18 to 45 inches.
4/2001 the precipitation range was narrowed to exclude less than 26 inches to limit this series to the typic-udic moisture regime.
Classification revised from Typic to Eutric Glossocryalf to accommodate base saturation of 60 to 100 percent in range in characteristics.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
